--- title: "In-class Ex 1" subtitle: "" author: "Stephen Tay" date: "26 Aug 2024" date-modified: "last-modified" execute: eval: true echo: true message: false freeze: true --- # 1. Getting Started ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(sf, tmap, tidyverse, ggstatsplot) ``` ::: # 2. Importing and Writing Geospatial Data ::: panel-tabset ## Importing shapefile format In this example, we are importing the Master Plan Planning Subzone Data 2014. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz14_shp <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source `/Users/stephentay/stephentay/ISSS626-Geospatial-Analytics/In-class_Ex/In-class_Ex01/data/geospatial' using driver `ESRI Shapefile' Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33 Projected CRS: SVY21 ``` ::: ::: ## Writing geospatial data to KML file format To write geospatial data to kml file format, you could use `st_write`. When setting `delete_dsn` argument to `TRUE`, it overwrites any existing file in the folder. If the argument is set to `FALSE`, it will yield an error if there is already an existing file in the folder. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} st_write(mpsz14_shp, "data/geospatial/MP_SUBZONE_WEB_PL.kml", delete_dsn = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Deleting source `data/geospatial/MP_SUBZONE_WEB_PL.kml' using driver `KML' Writing layer `MP_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' to data source `data/geospatial/MP_SUBZONE_WEB_PL.kml' using driver `KML' Writing 323 features with 15 fields and geometry type Multi Polygon. ``` ::: ::: ::: # 3. Working with Master Plan Planning Subzone Data 2019 ## 3.1 Importing dataset In this section, we will import the Master Plan Planning Subzone Data 2019 (MPSZ19) both in kml and shapefile format. As part of EDA, we should compare the two files to understand the data and identify any issues with the data before proceeding further. ::: panel-tabset ## MPSZ19 KML file format We see that this dataset is not ideal for analysis as it only provides the simple feature geometry, but does not provide any useful details of each simple feature. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz19_kml <- st_read("data/geospatial/MasterPlan2019SubzoneBoundaryNoSeaKML.kml") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Reading layer `URA_MP19_SUBZONE_NO_SEA_PL' from data source `/Users/stephentay/stephentay/ISSS626-Geospatial-Analytics/In-class_Ex/In-class_Ex01/data/geospatial/MasterPlan2019SubzoneBoundaryNoSeaKML.kml' using driver `KML' Simple feature collection with 332 features and 2 fields Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XY, XYZ Bounding box: xmin: 103.6057 ymin: 1.158699 xmax: 104.0885 ymax: 1.470775 z_range: zmin: 0 zmax: 0 Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} head(mpsz19_kml) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Simple feature collection with 6 features and 2 fields Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XYZ Bounding box: xmin: 103.8013 ymin: 1.274155 xmax: 103.8532 ymax: 1.286517 z_range: zmin: 0 zmax: 0 Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 Name 1 kml_1 2 kml_2 3 kml_3 4 kml_4 5 kml_5 6 kml_6 Description 1

(((103.8486 ... ``` ::: ::: ## MPSZ19 shapefile format Unlike the kml file, the shapefile dataset provides the simple feature geometry, as well as the details of each simple feature. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz19_shp <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "MPSZ-2019") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Reading layer `MPSZ-2019' from data source `/Users/stephentay/stephentay/ISSS626-Geospatial-Analytics/In-class_Ex/In-class_Ex01/data/geospatial' using driver `ESRI Shapefile' Simple feature collection with 332 features and 6 fields Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 103.6057 ymin: 1.158699 xmax: 104.0885 ymax: 1.470775 Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} head(mpsz14_shp) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Simple feature collection with 6 features and 15 fields Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 24468.89 ymin: 28369.47 xmax: 32362.39 ymax: 30542.74 Projected CRS: SVY21 OBJECTID SUBZONE_NO SUBZONE_N SUBZONE_C CA_IND PLN_AREA_N 1 1 1 MARINA SOUTH MSSZ01 Y MARINA SOUTH 2 2 1 PEARL'S HILL OTSZ01 Y OUTRAM 3 3 3 BOAT QUAY SRSZ03 Y SINGAPORE RIVER 4 4 2014-12-05 26782.83 5 BM CENTRAL REGION CR 85D9ABEF0A40678F 2014-12-05 26201.96 6 BM CENTRAL REGION CR 9D286521EF5E3B59 2014-12-05 25358.82 Y_ADDR SHAPE_Leng SHAPE_Area geometry 1 29220.19 5267.381 1630379.3 MULTIPOLYGON (((31495.56 30... 2 29782.05 3506.107 559816.2 MULTIPOLYGON (((29092.28 30... 3 29974.66 1740.926 160807.5 MULTIPOLYGON (((29932.33 29... 4 29933.77 3313.625 595428.9 MULTIPOLYGON (((27131.28 30... 5 30005.70 2825.594 387429.4 MULTIPOLYGON (((26451.03 30... 6 29991.38 4428.913 1030378.8 MULTIPOLYGON (((25899.7 297... ``` ::: ::: ::: ## 3.2 Projection Transformation The CRS of `mpsz19` is in **WGS 84**, which is a Geographical Coordinate System, useful in GPS to pinpoint a specific location, and the unit of measurement is in decimal degree. However, it is not suitable for geospatial analysis as the distance measurement of decimal degree is distorted. We will need to transform it from geographic coordinate system to projected coordinate system. In this code, we could build a pipe to import the data and transform it to projected coordinate system. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mpsz19_shp <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", layer = "MPSZ-2019") %>% st_transform(crs = 3414) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Reading layer `MPSZ-2019' from data source `/Users/stephentay/stephentay/ISSS626-Geospatial-Analytics/In-class_Ex/In-class_Ex01/data/geospatial' using driver `ESRI Shapefile' Simple feature collection with 332 features and 6 fields Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON Dimension: XY Bounding box: xmin: 103.6057 ymin: 1.158699 xmax: 104.0885 ymax: 1.470775 Geodetic CRS: WGS 84 ``` ::: ::: # 4. Working with Aspatial Population Data We will be importing and transforming the Population data of Singapore Residents by Planning Area / Subzone, Age Group, Sex and Type of Dwelling, June 2023. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} popdata <- read_csv("data/aspatial/respopagesextod2023.csv") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Rows: 100928 Columns: 7 ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── Delimiter: "," chr (5): PA, SZ, AG, Sex, TOD dbl (2): Pop, Time ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data. ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} head(popdata) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 7 PA SZ AG Sex TOD Pop Time 1 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males HDB 1- and 2-Room … 0 2023 2 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males HDB 3-Room Flats 0 2023 3 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males HDB 4-Room Flats 10 2023 4 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males HDB 5-Room and Exe… 30 2023 5 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males HUDC Flats (exclud… 0 2023 6 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Centre 0_to_4 Males Condominiums and O… 40 2023 ``` ::: ::: We will need to aggregate the population data by the subzone and age group. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} popdata2023 <- popdata %>% group_by(PA, SZ, AG) %>% summarise(`POP` = sum(Pop)) %>% ungroup() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `summarise()` has grouped output by 'PA', 'SZ'. You can override using the `.groups` argument. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} colnames(popdata2023) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "PA" "SZ" "AG" "POP" ``` ::: ::: We use `pivot_wider` to "spread out" the age groups to become a wide table. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} popdata2023 <- popdata %>% group_by(PA, SZ, AG) %>% summarise(`POP` = sum(Pop)) %>% ungroup() %>% pivot_wider(names_from = AG, values_from = POP) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `summarise()` has grouped output by 'PA', 'SZ'. You can override using the `.groups` argument. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} colnames(popdata2023) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "PA" "SZ" "0_to_4" "10_to_14" "15_to_19" [6] "20_to_24" "25_to_29" "30_to_34" "35_to_39" "40_to_44" [11] "45_to_49" "50_to_54" "55_to_59" "5_to_9" "60_to_64" [16] "65_to_69" "70_to_74" "75_to_79" "80_to_84" "85_to_89" [21] "90_and_Over" ``` ::: ::: Now we can sum and create the respective columns: - YOUNG: age group 0-4 until age group 20-24, - ECONOMY ACTIVE: age group 25-29 until age group 60-64, - AGED: age group 65 and above, - TOTAL: all age groups, and - DEPENDENCY: the ratio between young and aged against economy active group ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} popdata2023 <- popdata2023 %>% mutate(YOUNG = rowSums(.[3:6]) + rowSums(.[14])) %>% mutate(`ECONOMY ACTIVE` = rowSums(.[7:13]) + rowSums(.[15])) %>% mutate(`AGED` = rowSums(.[16:21])) %>% mutate(`TOTAL` = rowSums(.[3:21])) %>% mutate(`DEPENDENCY` = (`YOUNG` + `AGED`) / `ECONOMY ACTIVE`) %>% select(`PA`, `SZ`, `YOUNG`, `ECONOMY ACTIVE`, `AGED`, `TOTAL`, `DEPENDENCY`) popdata2023 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 332 × 7 PA SZ YOUNG `ECONOMY ACTIVE` AGED TOTAL DEPENDENCY 1 Ang Mo Kio Ang Mo Kio Town Cen… 1240 2830 890 4960 0.753 2 Ang Mo Kio Cheng San 5150 15600 6580 27330 0.752 3 Ang Mo Kio Chong Boon 4620 14120 7060 25800 0.827 4 Ang Mo Kio Kebun Bahru 4320 12400 5640 22360 0.803 5 Ang Mo Kio Sembawang Hills 1840 3670 1420 6930 0.888 6 Ang Mo Kio Shangri-La 3810 9600 4320 17730 0.847 7 Ang Mo Kio Tagore 1870 4320 1790 7980 0.847 8 Ang Mo Kio Townsville 3750 11090 5390 20230 0.824 9 Ang Mo Kio Yio Chu Kang 0 0 0 0 NaN 10 Ang Mo Kio Yio Chu Kang East 1090 2410 880 4380 0.817 # ℹ 322 more rows ``` ::: :::
